item.title: Scores Dead in Bangladesh Building Collapse
item.description: The collapse of the eight-story building outside of Dhaka raised questions about safety standards among the country’s garment manufacturers.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: People gathered after the collapse of an eight-story building near Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Godrej Group Chairman Adi Godrej
item.description: Mr. Godrej offers advice on achieving high economic growth, winning investors’ confidence and more.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:credit: World Economic Forum, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Adi Godrej at the World Economic Forum in New Delhi on Nov. 7, 2012.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Jailed Nobel Laureate Liu Xiaobo Reading on Communism, Christianity, Gaining Weight
item.description: The jailed Nobel laureate Liu Xiaobo is reading on Russian intellectuals and Soviet Communism and Christianity, and gaining weight, said a lawyer defending a member of his extended family on fraud charges that supporters say are politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo and his wife Liu Xia, left, in an undated photo released by his family in October 2010. Mr. Liu was sentenced to 11 years in jail for subversion in 2009, and awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2010.

item.title: Australia Arrests Self-Proclaimed Head of Hacking Group
item.description: The man, who wasn’t named, has said he is the leader of the collective known as LulzSec, which claimed that it shut down the C.I.A.’s Web site in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 24
item.description: Racing to invest in Indonesia; France approves marriage for same-sex couples; worries about Al Qaeda in Nigeria; worldwide fame for a bakery in Alsace; and bigger prizes at Wimbledon.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: L'Oréal opened its biggest factory in the world in West Java, Indonesia, last November.

item.title: Shakuntala Devi, ‘Human Computer,’ Dies in India at 83
item.description: Ms. Devi’s lightning calculations amazed audiences and supported her family, even when she was a child.
item.dc:creator: By HARESH PANDYA

item.title: Myanmar Frees Group of Dissenters
item.description: Human rights groups said that the amnesty declared by President Thein Sein still left many abuses unaddressed.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Lebanese Firms Launder Drug Money and Finance Militant Groups, U.S. Says
item.description: The United States accused two Lebanese money exchange houses of helping launder funds for a drug trafficking ring and of financing the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Fate of Clerics Held in Syria Is Disputed
item.description: Despite reports from a Christian advocacy group and Al Jazeera that two kidnapped Syrian archbishops had been freed, there was no confirmation.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA

item.title: Senators Say Case Indicates That Problems Persist in Agencies’ Data Sharing
item.description: Members of the Senate Intelligence Committee questioned how the F.B.I. and the Department of Homeland Security apparently handled information about one of the suspects in the Boston Marathon bombings.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and JULIA PRESTON

item.title: Bombing Suspect Cites Islamic Extremist Beliefs as Motive
item.description: Investigators’ early portrait of the two brothers accused in the marathon bombings suggests they were driven by extremist Islamic beliefs and may have learned to build bombs on the Web.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL COOPER, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The body of Sean Collier, the M.I.T. officer killed in Boston, was carried into church for his funeral Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Bird Flu Spreads in China
item.description: China said Tuesday that the H7N9 bird flu had spread to a new area, confirming the first case in the eastern province of Shandong.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Radioactive Gases Suggest Test by North Korea
item.description: A United Nations agency tasked with looking for signs of nuclear explosions says it has detected radioactive gases that could be linked to a test by North Korea on Feb. 12.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: China and Japan Bristle Over Islands and a Shrine
item.description: Lawmakers in Tokyo visited a shrine whose symbolism has angered China, while the two nations squared off over contested islands.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Japanese vessels sailed near a Chinese surveillance ship near disputed islands called Senkaku in Japan and Diaoyu in China on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: British Man Convicted of Fraud Over Fake Bomb Detectors
item.description: A British businessman who sold the Iraqi security forces fake bomb detectors based on $20 golf ball finders bought from the United States was convicted of fraud on Tuesday in Britain.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: Syria Has Used Chemical Weapons, Israel Says
item.description: Tel Aviv made its most definitive statement accusing Syria of using chemical weapons, which President Obama has called a “red line” Syria cannot cross.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: U.S. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel met a group of Israeli soldiers during his visit to an army base near Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | Mideast: Resignations Continue in Egypt
item.description: President Mohamed Morsi faced a mounting revolt against Islamist attempts to force out thousands of judges when his own legal adviser quit on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Clashes at Sunni Protest Site in Iraq Kill Dozens
item.description: An attack on a Sunni protest encampment in a village near the northern city of Kirkuk raised the stakes sharply in Iraq’s sectarian troubles.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqi medics help an injured demonstrator after clashes between Iraqi soldiers and anti-government protesters in Kirkuk on Tuesday.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Suspects Appear in Court in Canada Over Charges in Derailment Plot
item.description: The two men charged with plotting to derail a Canadian passenger train with the assistance of Al Qaeda denied the charges in court appearances on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Judiciary Panel Hears Testimony on Use of Drones
item.description: In testimony before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee, a Yemeni man who had studied in the United States said the strikes turned Yemenis against America.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: In Nigeria, Ansaru Militant Group Poses New Threat
item.description: The Islamist group Ansaru, an offshoot of Boko Haram, says it eschews the killing of fellow Nigerians and prefers kidnapping and killing foreigners.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: A still image from a video released by the Islamist group Ansaru reportedly shows members speaking in November 2012.

item.title: Iran Shoppers, Fearing Price Increases, Hoard Goods
item.description: An unanticipated change in the country’s exchange-rate policy could raise prices of some foodstuffs by 60 percent or more.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Mont-St.-Michel Journal: Restoring the Sea and the Romance to Mont-St.-Michel
item.description: A $285 million project to restore Mont-St.-Michel as an island is touching the commercial heart of the town, confusing tourists and angering residents.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists leaving Mont-St.-Michel, where a $285 million project to remake it into an island has generated confusion and anger.

item.title: Vietnam Clings to Single-Party Rule as Dissent Rises Sharply
item.description: The Communist Party is divided into factions even as a better informed public is finding its voice.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Justin Mott for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: A slum in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. Wide dissatisfaction has followed the boom of the 1990s.

item.title: WORLD: Seeking Proof on Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: The Times’s David E. Sanger on what the Obama administration is looking for before it moves on intelligence suggesting that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria used chemical weapons.
